abstract.p: Dr Stanley S Bergen plans to retire from his post as University of Medicine and Dentistry's first and only president; Bergen, 67, will step down in June 1998 after 27 years (New Jersey Daily Briefing) (S)

block.p: Dr. Stanley S. Bergen, who built a small medical school into the nation's largest public health and science university, said yesterday that he plans to retire from his post as the University of Medicine and Dentistry's first and only president.

Dr. Bergen, 67, will step down in June 1998 after 27 years. During his tenure, the university endowment grew from less than $200,000 to more than $80 million, said Stuart M. Goldstein, a spokesman for the school.

Dr. Stanley S. Bergen, who built a small medical school into the nation's largest public health and science university, said yesterday that he plans to retire from his post as the University of Medicine and Dentistry's first and only president.

Dr. Bergen, 67, will step down in June 1998 after 27 years. During his tenure, the university endowment grew from less than $200,000 to more than $80 million, said Stuart M. Goldstein, a spokesman for the school.

The university now has three medical schools -- in New Brunswick, Newark and Stratford -- as well as schools for dentistry, nursing and health-related professions. It also has a graduate program in biomedical sciences.
